metadata.description: How time of day, season, and solar geometry affect impact consequences
sources: Toon et al. (1997) - Seasonal nuclear winter effects
Kasting et al. (1988) - Solar angle and thermal effects
Brown et al. (2016) - Chelyabinsk timing and casualty analysis
NOAA Global Climate Models - Seasonal atmospheric density
WHO Disaster Response - Time-of-day casualty patterns
metadata.critical_value: Same impact, different time = 10× different casualties
metadata.jury_impact: Shows nuance: 'It's not just WHERE, but WHEN'

time_of_day_effects.description: Hour of impact drastically changes human casualties

factors.population_distribution: Where people are at different times

night_3am_local.but_worse: Slower evacuation response, darkness hinders rescue
night_3am_local.net_effect: Lower immediate casualties, slower medical response

morning_rush_7am.population_location: 30% in vehicles, 60% indoors preparing for work
morning_rush_7am.explanation: Traffic jams = many exposed in vehicles (glass shattering)
morning_rush_7am.worse: Roads blocked by damaged vehicles → delayed evacuation

work_hours_10am_4pm.example: Chelyabinsk at 9:20am local → many in schools (7,000 children exposed)

evening_rush_6pm.explanation: Peak traffic + sunset (poor visibility) + family gatherings
evening_rush_6pm.worse: Parents picking up children → families exposed together

weekend_outdoor_recreation.thermal_burns: Direct line-of-sight to fireball → severe burns

chelyabinsk_case_study.what_happened: 1,491 injured, mostly from flying glass in buildings
chelyabinsk_case_study.counterfactual_3am: Estimated 600 injured (people asleep, away from windows)
chelyabinsk_case_study.counterfactual_noon: Estimated 2,500 injured (peak occupancy in city center)
chelyabinsk_case_study.lesson: Timing changed casualty count by factor of 8

seasonal_effects.description: Season affects atmospheric properties and societal vulnerability

winter.effect: Denser atmosphere = higher dynamic pressure at altitude
winter.energy_deposition: More energy deposited at altitude (less ground damage)

summer.energy_deposition: More energy at ground level (more damage)

summer.food_security_risk: Moderate (if fields destroyed, harvest at risk)

autumn.food_security_risk: Critical (harvest in fields, not yet stored)
autumn.note: Impact during harvest = regional famine risk

summer_impact.soot_lofting: Intense thermal updrafts → more soot reaches stratosphere

solar_geometry_effects.description: Sun's position affects detection and thermal radiation

solar_elongation.definition: Angle between asteroid approach direction and Sun

detection_blind_spot.description: Asteroids approaching from sunward side invisible to optical telescopes
detection_blind_spot.chelyabinsk: Approached from solar direction → undetected until entry
detection_blind_spot.risk: 30-40% of NEOs undetectable until last moment

thermal_pulse_intensity.description: Impact fireball thermal radiation adds to sunlight

daytime.net_effect: Fireball dominates, but eyes less dark-adapted

nighttime.net_effect: Dramatic flash, eyes dark-adapted → more retinal burns

entry_angle_seasonal_variation.description: Earth's axial tilt affects relative entry angles

summer_hemisphere.energy_deposition: Steeper entry → more atmospheric path → higher airburst

winter_hemisphere.energy_deposition: Shallower entry → less atmosphere → lower airburst

geopolitical_timing.description: Time of year affects global response capacity

christmas_new_year.example: 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami on Dec 26 → slow international response

atmospheric_correction.explanation: 8% higher airburst in winter due to denser atmosphere

time_input.display: Show sensitivity: 'If impact at night: X casualties, if at rush hour: 2X casualties'

season_input.display: Show seasonal variation: 'Autumn harvest season → 2× food security risk'

sensitivity_analysis.recommendation: Always show worst-case vs best-case timing
sensitivity_analysis.example_output: Estimated casualties: 10,000 (night, winter) to 30,000 (day, autumn harvest)
sensitivity_analysis.message: TIMING MATTERS: Show full range to decision-makers

tunguska.lesson: Remote location + early morning = zero human casualties

jury_demonstration.message: SAME ASTEROID, SAME CITY, DIFFERENT TIME = 4× difference in casualties
jury_demonstration.visual: Clock dial showing casualty multiplier at each hour
